title: John Mayer Font
content:
Alright I've been trying to ID this for a while. I know that for some of Mr. Mayer's stuff (website/iTunes artist page) he uses Avant Garde and I think that's what they're using here but the Rs are DEFINITELY not avant garde.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100719013507im_/http:/typophile.com/files/JM_4675.jpg)

Obviously this is a custom font... but what are it's roots?

After doing a "What The Font?" On the John Mayer album cover for continuum, and it came up as News Gothic BT -- the R from that appears to match so perhaps its a combo of both I don't know.

[john mayer.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20100719013507/http:/www.johnmayer.com/)  
 [continuum album cover](http://web.archive.org/web/20100719013507/http:/www.j-mayer.org/images/career/musichistory/continuum-big.jpg)
author: adamschoales

comments.content:
Looks like Avenir(?, experts..please help:P)... but it's obviously been modified somewhat

The Rs look like Avenir...the JOHN MAYER part it seems to be it..although the middle rung of the E has been shortened. The S on summer looks like Avant Garde, def. not Avenir. Gee..what a mess
Well I'm pretty sure that most of it comes from Avant Garde (only because I know thats what has been used in the past and on lots of other materials) but that damn R...
I donâ€™t see any Avant Garde in that.

[[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/trade-gothic/|Trade Gothic]] seems fairly close, but the J has a bit less hook than your sample. The ligatures are probably why Avant Garde was suggested, but I think those may be customized from the font used, and not necessarily part of the font.

- Mike Yanega

There are four attributes that I was trying to match: the J (above the baseline and fairly closed); the M (straight-sided, with vertex at baseline); the E (short center arm); and the R (straight leg intersecting the bowl). The closest sample I had in my Sans Guide was Berthold Balken, which I cannot find any more. However, it was condensed by comparison to this sample, so it was not an exact match unless it had been widened.

Yehan's suggestion of [Avenir](http://web.archive.org/web/20100719013507/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/avenir/), does not have the uneven E, but it looks a lot like it in other respects, so let's say Avenir, with a modified E, and manufactured ligatures. This would get you very close.

- Mike Yanega

Here's the version I whipped up last night in illustrator using Avant Garde as my base (though I forget what I used to make the R). I found it to be closer than avenir, at least to my eyes...
